title: Plenary Session: Interregional Cooperation on OER

author: Yves Punie, Information Society Unit, Institute for Prospective Technological Studies, Joint Research Centre, European Commission

segmentation: I would like to share with you how we look at within Europe.
Developments related to open indication and ovr's.

So that's why my title is going open in Europe, but I'm looking at it from the point of view of research, because as you see there, the logo of the European Commission I am part of the European Commission, but I'm not representing the Commission in terms of its policy agenda.
We are part of the GFC is called the Joint Research Centers, which are the in House Research Laboratory of the European Commission and what we do is we do study and analysis and evidence.
To support European policy makers and European policies in many, many different areas.
And of course in our area related to education and skills and and inclusion.
Just to share with you that we've been actually working with this and severe for more than 10 years on ICT for learning and skills.
We have published more than 100 scientific reports with the aim to support European Member States policies within Europe on the digital transformation of education and training.
Antonen addressing 21st century skills challenges.
That, of course, includes also open education, and we look at on purpose open education.
We look at our yards, we look at nooks.
We look at recognition, teacher training and other kind of elements.
And that's actually up.
So that's the first point.
I want to make is that we look at it from the point of view of open education and open indication for us is not only are not just about books.

Not just or not only about Ojars, although very very important, but for US it's about widening access to education opportunities, ensuring participation for all, and also about the needed modernization and innovating innovation of education and training enabled by digital technologies.
Because, for example, and I think also it was already discussed in the in the in the first day Planner here at the conference.
Oers play a key role.

But if you look at widening access to education that are, for example, a lot of free online learning opportunities which are not necessarily or we are a lot of books which are not necessarily openly licensed but which widen access to education, and we look at it from that point of view.

We have several projects and one of them is called to open it to project, which we do on behalf of the Giac where we look at especially how we can help education institutions in Europe to open up in their activities.
Let me see.
OK, so this was the.
This is my old slide set.

Actually it's not the most recent one, but anyway doesn't matter where we look at how we can help opening the case in institutions dealing with opening up education, and we've done a number of studies you can see there open cases.
A number of case studies on opening up education within institutions in Europe, Open credits about how to recognize MC learning credentials and certifications related to MC Learning.
We did a survey, open survey, surveying 5.
Countries in Europe.
Representative survey of how institutions deal with Oers with opening up.
For example, there we, we demonstrate, or we showed that almost half of all the universities in these five counters in Europe are somehow dealing with with opening up some deal with MOX.
Some deal with Open Access, some deal with Oers, and so we have more data on that and also MC knowledge is a survey we have with MC learners and all this research actually led to.
What we go?
The opening up education framework for high rated higher education institutions.
And here you have a summary of of that research which actually tries to highlight 10 dimensions of open education.
So our aim was here to actually to clarify because many people have many different understandings.
What we mean with open education with ovr and books etc etc.
And in this report we try to clarify all these 10 dimensions related to open education.
We have 4.
Transversal dimensions dealing with strategy, technology, quality and leadership.
And then we have six inner dimensions.
One of them's content, for example, and obviously ovr fits into that, but also free online license kind of content as well.
Look at pedagogies and how pedagogies need to need to be adapted to take into account opening open education.
Look at the recognition of learning.
Collaboration is a very very important, very important part of that, because we claim that.

If you open up your activities, it will also facilitate collaboration and cooperation with other stakeholders and actives importance of research, Open Access and the importance of widening access to education.
So in that report, we explain that in detail, so I cannot go further on that.
But just to highlight that we advocate a broader kind of you.
It's more like a kind of a holistic kind of you, arguing that we have to take all these dimensions into account.
If you want to.
Widen access and if you want to open education especially POV of higher education.
And institutions.
We then go.

We go from institutional view to policies and actually we are finalizing now a study of the policies that exist in Europe in the 28 European Member State countries on open Education desk research, analysis of these policies in the 28 Member States and we did also number of workshops with policymakers and stakeholders and I would very briefly want like to share some of the results of this study with you.

One of the main messages that may be probably very obvious, but you know still to highlight that all stakeholders we consulted, ministries, experts etc confirmed that it's still very, very important to develop good, visible and encompassing policies to, you know as a catalyst for accent and to you know to advance more in the area.
But a bit more specific, and actually this was also mentioned already in I've seen and Twitter.
Also some of the slides and other sessions where we made an analysis with what we find in Europe that they actually four types of policies on open education.

This is also maybe not a big surprise to you, but the first one is that you find specific policies on open education promoting our yard, open educational practices, and the first quarter to the left to the right you see more digital education policies which have some element of open education and there we go down to the left where you then see more broader educational policies, which takes some elements of digital and open into account.
And in the fourth quadrant we also found policies in Europe related to open government Open Access, which were also quite significant.
This helps us a bit to understand also where to place and how to.
See further develop open education.
I think it's fine also to highlight that diversity which we find in Europe relate.
The policies and then in the study we gave some we give some examples on how this specifically works.
On the first one we have specific policies are not being open.
Education you see in France, the Fund initiative or nukes, Slovenia, opening up Slovenia, Germany as important quality on IR and ICT in education policy with some elements of open education.
We have examples from Cyprus, Ireland, Lithuania, broader education strategies.
We have examples from Creation Czech Republic, Estonia.
A more open government policy is we have examples from Greece, Romania and Slovakia and we describe all these policies in the report.
Actually, we're going to publish very, very soon.

To summarize, the results from these studies, we highlight actually an also stakeholders and ministers highlight that what we need to do is we need to try to go to an ecosystem and open education ecosystem where the mindset is open and this is the default mindset and a number of issues have been highlighted and I think there are many of them are not a big surprise to you just to confirm the importance.
Again of awareness raising.
Still many many people and many many teachers.
Another word of the potential of open education.
There was a recent study in Scotland which really demonstrated at the level of knowledge of teachers in Scotland, where awareness on or we are very very very low awareness.
Raising still remains very important, the importance of regulation, legislation and funding.
Of course, the promotion of partnerships teacher professional developed professional development that was also mentioned by the Speaker before me.
The importance of activation and recognition of learning.
Open educational resources.
Obviously as well.
We would still need also the support infrastructures you need access.

You need infrastructures, alot of support mechanisms are still necessary and also finally the importance of research and evaluation highlighting that sometimes also both are to look at policies that many policies are being developed, but very few of them are actually being analyzed.
If they have an impact.
If they make a difference.
And that's also a lot with our initiatives.
Very often we do a lot of initiatives and we promote and we develop a lot of materials, but there's very little research to actually demonstrate how it is changing pedagogies.
Howard is providing more access, so we need also more analysis and more research related to that.
In the report, as I say, you have these eight elements, you will find more specific policy recommendations for all these eight kind of elements, and this one is a screenshot from the one ovr.
Well, you see, we make a difference between messages for at the European level at the national level and at the regional level.

And for example, we say here our stakeholders, you know emphasize the European Commission should take a lead to be a catalyst of boyar adoption, reuse and use, and there was already some example given also by the Commissioner here 2 days ago, who said that now in Erasmus Plus programme all resources publicly funded?
By the government by the European Commission has to be openly licensed and provide freely to everybody.
So that's one important element.

And then we also have some some guidelines for ministries here, highlighting, for example the importance of teacher training ministry shouldn't be involved in promoting teacher training, so that teachers learn also better to deal with and find Oyarzun Dylan use them into their practicians into their practices and roll for regional authorities as well.
To be partners.
To be Co responsible for our production and use and to explore.
Also how we ask and be fit into regional strategies.
Regional economic strategies and also regional inclusion strategies.
Just give a brief example because we have obviously much more in the report, but.
We don't have time and I'm rounding up.
We don't have time to go to the details.
The overall policy recommendations if you want suggested by the participants in this research.
Other following European Commission should consider mediating and supporting the creation of an open of European open education ecosystem.
An ecosystem would help to scale up open education projects and support the mindset change and that's really really very important.
The mindset change which could lead also to organizational scene.
So I will stay colder than Europe really.
See a very, very important role for the European Commission to take a vision and leadership here, although obviously I must also say thinking about an open education ecosystem.
It's probably much easier said than done.
You know it's not so obvious, but it is important to emphasize ministries to take action in partnership with stakeholders and open education.
And there again, the issue of partnership is very very, very important.
But we don't want to give the impression that this can be done alone.
This needs to be done in partnership and regions should consider providing capacity.
Building an open education deal with educators work.
Again, in partnership with ministries, funding and Co. Funding and Co.
Managing and open education initiatives.
So these are more.

These are the more kind of over more kind of broad conclusions and some what we argue for and what we see from the research that contemporary as we call it open education goals for multi stakeholder actions.
This is not a cannot be the exclusive domain of 1 institution of 1 School of the University or a ministry.
Openness can and should be promoted by all.
In order to achieve transparency, collaboration and above all, social accountability in educational practices.
So these reports, which I'm referring to will be published very, very soon end of September.
We have the first report going open, policy recommendations on open education in Europe and the supporting study with the analysis of the policies in the 28 Member States end of October.
Thank you for your attention.
